Cancelling Tough Skin
Monster Rancher Metropolis: Monster Rancher 3 Archive (PS2): Characteristics: Cancelling Tough Skin
By Nate Railsback on Tuesday, November 6, 2001 - 12:11 pm:

I raised a Zan to go in my line of Speed & Power-based monsters, and since I needed the encyclopedia entry, I evolved it into a Retsu. Unfortunately, this means it picked up Tough Skin, which does NOT play in well with a speedster. I know that if you include Fast Footwork on a creature with Tough Skin/Tough Scales/Stone Body/etc., the two will cancel out. My question is, is there any other similar trait to Fast Footwork? Since the whole defense up/evade down trait has several different versions, I wanted to know if the opposite had them, too, or if I'll have to raise a Hare to cancel things out (and I don't really care about Hares).

By torey_luvullo on Tuesday, November 6, 2001 - 12:21 pm:

fast footwork did not cancel out armor, when i fed a hare heart to a durahan. we may have to develop a list of specific traits that do and don't cancel out other specific traits

By Nate Railsback on Tuesday, November 6, 2001 - 03:42 pm:

Well, when I say "cancel out," I don't mean that they both dissappear. I mean that if they're both on there, unless one is "more powerful" than the other, they neutralize each other by activating at the same time. Evade up, Defense Down + Defense Up, Evade Down = Net of zero. Which is what I'd like to get back to...

Hmmm....if I could just transfer my Zan's heart to a Joker (which I had already considered), its Illusion Cape would cancel out the evasion problem but still leave the defense boost intact...also, is there anything that CAN'T have Tough Skin? Because there are obviously a lot of things that can't have Stone Body...or is Tough Skin like Sharp Eyes, and moves freely to any creature? If I can shake it rather than neutralize it, so much the better.

By ChetFlavin on Tuesday, November 6, 2001 - 05:44 pm:

It does cancel out, 2 examples.

1.While being attacked 2 defence enhancing charecteristics(can't remember names) showed up with clear circles next to them with a red circle showing up next to fast footwork.

2.While attacking an opponent a fast footwork charecteristic came up for them with a red circle while for my monster the charecteristic sharp eyes came up with a green circle.

But these incidences don't occur all the time. So even if you can forget one charecteristic it still won't make a major difference that one charecteristic will all of a sudden start exceding, its all probability.

By Lao on Wednesday, November 7, 2001 - 12:45 am:

Intuition works a lot like fast footwork, except that I don't think it has FF's downside of increasing damage when a hit occurs. I've seen Intuition spontaneously develop (not from exploration) during growth in two Raidens.

I'm not buying into discussions of "cancelling" in the way that you're implying, ChetFlavin, without seeing some numbers. I've seen no evidence to suggest that Armor or ToughSkin reduce damage exactly as much as Fast Footwork increases it. If, for instance, ToughSkin drops damage by 20% and evade by 10% and Fast Footwork increases damage by 10% and evade by 20%, then having both would be worthwhile overall.

And on the general topic, I raised a Pow/Spd Zan that had Armor, and I firmly believe that the characteristic was what made him able to compete so well at high levels with only mediocre life/def.

Also, as Torey said, those traits don't cancel each other in the sense that they cannot exist on the same monster at the same time--they can. I think we've gotten some terminology confusion here.

By ChetFlavin on Wednesday, November 7, 2001 - 06:27 am:

I didn't say they would always cancle eachother out, get rid of eachother completly, or that the charecteristics were delt with in an EXACT way. I said its all probability.Besides the way you seem to understand what I said Lao is that they all produced there effect so that Armor and Thick Fur(those def. enhancers i mentioned earlier) would activate and cancel out Fast Footwork. What I meant is that the green circle didn't show up meaning it wasn't working. Now if anyone thinks that the green,red, and clear circles don't mean anything to whether a charecteristic works or not then why were they put in the game?

By Nate Railsback on Wednesday, November 7, 2001 - 12:31 pm:

I don't quite understand what ChetFlavin is trying to say...on either of his posts. Could you try summarizing?

By ChetFlavin on Wednesday, November 7, 2001 - 02:07 pm:

I guess it is kind of confusing, but anyways all I am saying is that some charecteristics conflict with others to where sometimes neither will work in a battle. There are also sometimes where an enemies charecteristic will beat out your own charecteristic and vice versa. So far in my experience I have come to believe that it is all random.
